revision.text:
{{Japanese name|Tsukitei and Yamasaki}} {{Infobox comedian | name = Hōsei Tsukitei | image = Hosei Tsukitei IMG 7476 20130831.JPG | birth_name = Hōsei Yamasaki | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1968|2|15}} | birth_place = [[Nishinomiya, Hyōgo]], Japan | medium = [[Owarai]]
[[Television]] | nationality = Japanese | active = 1988 – Present | genre = [[Rakugo]]
[[Owarai]] }} {{nihongo|'''Hōsei Tsukitei'''|月亭 方正|Tsukitei Hōsei}}, formerly known as {{nihongo|'''Hōsei Yamasaki'''|山崎 邦正|Yamasaki Hōsei| born February 15, 1968}} is a Japanese solo comedian and ''[[rakugo]]'' performer, signed with [[Yoshimoto Kogyo]]. He is best known for being one of the five members (and the only solo comedian) of [[Downtown no Gaki no Tsukai ya Arahende!!|Downtown Gaki no Tsukai]]'s regular cast. His role on the show is usually divided up between the ''suberi-kyara'' and the ''ijime-kyara''. Outside of ''Gaki no Tsukai'', he has released three books, a CD single of his signature "Yamazaki Ichi-ban!" song, and has appeared in several Yoshimoto Kogyo compilations and DVD releases. ==Early life== Hōsei was born in [[Nishinomiya, Hyōgo]] where from the age of five he took an interest in [[Kendo]],{{cite episode |title=Geinō-kai Tokugi-ō Kettei-sen TEPPEN |script-title=ja:芸能界特技王決定戦TEPPEN |trans-title=Showbiz Skills Playoffs TEPPEN |network=[[Fuji Television|Fuji TV]] |date=3 August 2010}} later joining a high school Kendo club.{{cite episode |title=Gaki no Tsukai Zettai ni Waratte wa Ike Nai Kōkō |script-title=ja:ガキの使い絶対に笑ってはいけない高校 |trans-title=Gaki no Tsukai No-Laughing High School (2005) |network=[[Nippon TV|NTV]] |date=4 October 2005}} He attended Nishinomiya South High School {{cite web |url=http://www.hyogo-c.ed.jp/~nishiminami-hs/gakkoutyou/g_aisatu.html |script-title=ja:ようこそ西宮南高等学校のホームページへ |access-date=29 June 2015 |language=Japanese |trans-title=Nishinomiya South High School Welcome Homepage}} where being humorous was a desirable trait, popular among fellow students they coined the term {{nihongo|''kawaikkoii''|かわいっこいい|"cute / cool"}} for him.{{cite episode |title=FROM ZERO |series=NEWS ZERO |network=[[Yomiuri Telecasting Corporation|YTV]] |date=24 October 2014}} ==Career== ===New Star Creation (1987–1988)=== After graduating from high school, Hōsei joined [[Yoshimoto Kogyo]]'s 6th NSC (New Star Creation) [[Osaka]]-based school group in April 1987.{{cite web |url=http://lemontree.gozaru.jp/school/nsc_o1.html |script-title=ja:NSC大阪1期～10期生卒業生リスト |access-date=29 June 2015 |language=Japanese |trans-title=NSC Osaka Phase 1 to 10 Graduates List}} In 1988 he teamed up with Hiromitsu Noriyasu {{cite web |url=http://www.sandiegoyuyu.com/index.php/features/features-news/interviews-en/618-yuyu-interview-hiromitsu-noriyasu |title=YuYu interview Hiromitsu Noriyasu |date=30 April 2007 |website=San Diego YuYu |access-date=29 June 2015}} to form the ''[[owarai]]'' duo GSX (ガスペケ) who performed at the Yoshimoto-run {{nihongo|'''Shinsaibashi Ni-chōme'''|心斎橋筋2丁目}} theater alongside many other recruits and graduates, such as [[Downtown (Owarai)|Downtown]], [[Itsuji Itao]], Koji Higashino and Imada Koji.{{cite web |url=http://astand.asahi.com/entertainment/starfile/OSK201302190065.html |script-title=ja:アンチ吉本・お笑いレボリューション |date=19 February 2013 |access-date=29 June 2015 |language=Japanese |trans-title=Anti-Yoshimoto, Comedy Revolution}} ===Team Zero (1989–1993)=== In 1989, Hōsei and Hiromitsu Noriyasu made the move to [[Tokyo]] and renamed themselves as {{nihongo|'''Team Zero'''|チーム0}}, appearing on the nationwide '''DAY BREAK''' show. Around the same time, [[Downtown (Owarai)|Downtown]] also moved on to [[Tokyo]] and Team Zero were frequent guests or regulars of their shows including '''[[Downtown no Gaki no Tsukai ya Arahende!!]]''', '''Downtown Nari''' and '''Downtown Juice'''. In addition to appearing in [[Yoshimoto Kogyo]] sponsored shows such as '''Yoshimoto Village''', they also starred in the '''Funky Monkey Teacher''' series alongside [[Jimmy Onishi]]. Their efforts won them the ''Best Newcomer Award'' at [[Asahi Broadcasting Corporation|ABC]]'s '''12th Rookie Comedian Grand Prix''' on January 15, 1991.{{cite web |url=http://www.geinin.jp/prize/category/abcowaraishinjin.html |title=受賞データ ABCお笑い新人グランプリ |access-date=30 June 2015 |language=Japanese |trans-title=Winners of ABC's Rookie Comedian Grand Prix}} However, Hōsei's comedy partner Hiromitsu Noriyasu found a passion for film directing and by the end of September 1993, Team Zero decided to part ways towards their own solo careers. ===Solo debut (1994–1997)=== In addition to his regular appearances on [[Downtown (Owarai)|Downtown]]'s shows such as '''[[Downtown no Gaki no Tsukai ya Arahende!!|Gaki no Tsukai]]''' and '''Downtown Kazaana''', in 1994 Hōsei also became a regular on '''Tenshi no U・B・U・G''', a late night show hosted by Imada Koji and Koji Higashino. Initially he received much attention for his young appearance, however as his role in comedy gradually cemented towards being the ''{{Nihongo|hetare|へたれ|hopeless}} [[#Suberi-kyara|suberi-kyara]]'', his public image quickly changed. Work began to dry up and Hōsei considered quitting comedy until he was amused by an episode of '''Mutsugoro & Fun Friends''', where a little [[Pug]] dog barked loudly and hopelessly confronted a large [[St. Bernard (dog)|St. Bernard]].{{cite episode |title=Mutsugoro & Fun Friends |script-title=ja:ムツゴロウとゆかいな仲間たち |network=[[Fuji Television|Fuji TV]] |date=9 January 1994}} Taking the underdog as inspiration he tried raising his voice and taking on comically hopeless confrontations, as seen in his ''[[#Ijime-kyara|ijime-kyara]]'' role, which brought in more work offers.{{cite episode |title=Kusano Kid |script-title=ja:草野☆キッド |network=[[Asahi Broadcasting Corporation|ABC]] |date=10 June 2009}}{{cite web |url=http://blog.livedoor.jp/apipo/archives/51671803.html |script-title=ja:パグ師匠 |date=10 June 2009 |access-date=30 June 2015 |language=Japanese |trans-title=Pug Teacher}}{{cite episode |title=Hon'ne no dendō! ! Shinsuke ni wa Wakaru mai |script-title=ja:ホンネの殿堂!!紳助にはわかるまいっ |network=[[Fuji Television|Fuji TV]] |date=4 October 2009}} Hōsei appeared in a number of direct-to-video releases,{{cite episode |series=[[Downtown no Gaki no Tsukai ya Arahende!!]] |title=No-Laughing Enthusiastic Teachers |network=[[Nippon TV|NTV]] |date=31 December 2012}} including starring roles in the live-action [[manga]] adaptations of [[Chameleon (manga)|'''Chameleon''']] and '''Pappakapā'''. In addition he took on roles within sitcoms, including a semi-regular part as a visiting fishmonger in '''Pokkapoka''', and a regular part in [[Ken Shimura]]'s sitcom '''Heisei Shimura Family''' where, although he was 28 ~ 30 at the time, he played the role of the 20 ~ 22-year-old son. With '''Denpa Shōnen International''' he made a number of trips abroad to take on dangerous challenges such as meeting [[the Mafia]] in [[Italy]], participating in the [[Running of the Bulls]] in [[Spain]] and searching for the [[Chupacabra]] in [[Mexico]].{{cite web |url=http://www.ntv.co.jp/denpa/dvd/index.html |title=DVD情報電波少年的電波少年 |access-date=30 June 2015 |language=Japanese |trans-title=Denpa Shōnen DVD Info}} ===Children's television (1998–2000)=== Hōsei became a children's television presenter on the long-running '''Tensai Terebi-kun''' series, which also included performing in a number of stage plays.{{cite episode |title=From Here Interview - Rakugoka Tsukitei Hosei |script-title=ja:インタビューここから落語家月亭方正 |network=[[NHK]] |date=24 November 2014}} On set he mentored child actor '''[[Eiji Wentz]]''' who formally became his apprentice.{{cite episode |series=[[Hey! Hey! Hey! Music Champ]] |network=[[Fuji Television|Fuji TV]] |date=21 November 2005}} ===Entertainment work (2000–present)=== As a solo comedian, Hōsei flits between various regular and irregular appearances on variety shows. From 2000 he co-hosted an [[Mainichi Broadcasting System|MBS]] internet radio talk show called {{Nihongo|''K'zStation Ore-tachi Yattemasu''|K'zStationオレたちやってま〜す}}, mentioning it as one of his only regular sources of work on [[Downtown no Gaki no Tsukai ya Arahende!!|Gaki no Tsukai]]'s No Laughing series in 2006.{{cite episode |series=[[Downtown no Gaki no Tsukai ya Arahende!!]] |title=No-Laughing Police Station |network=[[Nippon TV|NTV]] |date=31 December 2006}} He began appearing yearly on the '''Drive A Go! Go!''' travel program, today his travels mainly focus on [[onsens]] around Japan.{{cite web |url=http://www.tv-tokyo.co.jp/drive/backnumber/ |title=Drive Go! Past Episodes List |access-date=30 June 2015 |language=Japanese}} Between 2003–2005 he frequently appeared on '''Ametalk''', establishing a weekly segment where [[Ameagari Kesshitai]] would intrude upon him whilst strangely dressed, leading to a comical confrontation with [[Hiroyuki Miyasako]] that would inevitably lead to Hōsei's defeat.{{cite web |url=http://www.tv-asahi.co.jp/ametalk/dvd_new/archives/index.html |title=アメトーークDVD&ブルーレイラインナップ |access-date=30 June 2015 |language=Japanese |trans-title=Ametalk DVD & Blu-ray List}} From 2005 onward he appeared more infrequently as a talk show guest. He often performs in [[Yoshimoto Kogyo]] stage shows, particularly at the '''Lumine the Yoshimoto''' theater where he became known for the catchphrases {{Nihongo|''Ma~''|マー}} and {{Nihongo|''Yatta Ja~n''|やったじゃ～ん}}.{{cite web |url=http://www.excite.co.jp/News/reviewbook/20130304/E1362324600397.html |title=Why I Became a Rakugo Book Review |date=4 March 2013 |website=Excite |language=Japanese}} Every so often he takes on drama or film roles such as in '''Tears of Kitty''' or the more recent '''Mentai Piriri 2'''. After graduating as a [[#Rakugo|rakugo]] he moved to [[Osaka]] but continues to work as a solo comedian within the entertainment industry, typically on [[Kansai region]] shows such as '''Osaka Honwaka TV''' and '''Marco Polori''', whilst maintaining his regular role on '''[[Downtown no Gaki no Tsukai ya Arahende!!|Gaki no Tsukai]]''' in the [[Kantō region]]. He is a frequent guest on variety talk shows such as '''Uramayo''' and '''Kaitetsu! Emi Channel'''. Alongside comedian friend '''Jinnai Tomonori''' and his mentor '''Tsukitei Happo''' he regularly hosts the '''Yoshimoto Golden Biographies''' series, interviewing various [[Yoshimoto Kogyo]] comedians about their lives. ===Rakugo (2008–present)=== In 2008 Hōsei turned 40 and with the sense that he was going through the motions coupled with the public's dwindling reception he was feeling at a loss.{{cite episode |title=Gion Laugh |script-title=ja:祇園笑者 |network=[[Yomiuri Telecasting Corporation|YTV]] |date=12 December 2014}} After seeking advice from '''Koji Higashino''',{{cite web |script-title=ja:月亭方正落語家転身は東野幸治さんの助言がきっかけ |url=http://headlines.yahoo.co.jp/hl?a=20140126-00000002-wordleaf-ent |trans-title=How Tsukitei Hōsei Turned Rakugo after Koji Higashino's Advice |date=26 January 2014 |website=Yahoo! Japan |language=Japanese}} Hōsei began to listen to performer [[Shijaku Katsura II]], which sparked a passion for [[rakugo]]. He began practicising alone for around six months before approaching rakugo performer '''Tsukitei Hachimitsu''' who introduced him to his father, rakugo master '''Tsukitei Happo'''. Happo gave him the chance to perform the comical story {{Nihongo|'''Amida Pond'''|阿弥陀池}} for an audience on 11 May 2008 then invited him to a [[nomikai]] where Hōsei requested an apprenticeship. Happo accepted and thereafter mentored Hōsei for 5 years before submitting an application for him to officially join rakugo society.{{cite web |url=http://news.mynavi.jp/articles/2010/07/09/housei/001.html |script-title=ja:山崎邦正、落語家人生を語る |trans-title=Yamazaki Hōsei's Tale of Rakugo Life |date=9 July 2010 |website=Mynavi News |language=Japanese}} However, at first there was some reluctance from the governing board as a large part of his prior experience was unrelated to rakugo.{{cite episode |title=Yoshimoto Golden Biographies Special |script-title=ja:よしもと黄金列伝!SP |network=[[Yomiuri Telecasting Corporation|YTV]] |date=30 August 2014}} Tsukitei Happo appealed the decision and he was permitted to graduate, whereupon he adopted the title Tsukitei Hōsei from 2013 onwards.{{cite web |url=http://www.tokyohive.com/article/2012/12/comedian-yamasaki-hosei-to-change-his-name-starting-in-2013 |title=Yamasaki Hōsei To Change His Name |date=18 December 2012 |website=TokyoHive}} He later published a book titled "Why I Became a Rakugo".{{cite book |last=Hōsei |first=Tsukitei |date=January 2013 |script-title=ja:僕が落語家になった理由 |trans-title=Why I Became a Rakugo |language=Japanese |isbn=978-4-7572-2159-8}} In an effort to pursue rakugo further, Hōsei moved to [[Osaka]] with his family, where the Tsukitei group is based.{{cite web |url=http://hassyoutei.com/access/ |title=Access to Pavilion |access-date=30 June 2015 |website=Hassyoutei}} He now regularly performs at rakugo theaters and festivals around Japan, including charity events.{{cite web |url=http://news.mynavi.jp/articles/2010/07/09/housei/001.html |title=Tsukitei Hōsei at Genkidama Japan |date=16 October 2013 |website=Yahoo Japan Blog |language=Japanese}} At his first major solo rakugo performance, he received congratulatory flowers from '''Natsumi Ogawa''' ([[Masatoshi Hamada]]'s wife), which he later handed out to attendees as thanks.{{cite web |url=https://twitter.com/tukiteihousei/status/393650546684329984 |script-title=ja:菜摘さんからお花 |date=25 October 2013 |language=Japanese |trans-title=Flower's from Natsumi |website=Twitter}} As rakugo stories are traditionally learnt by listening, Hōsei uses a [[portable media player]] with around 2,500 rakugo performances to help with memorization. ==Skills== ===Music=== Hōsei has a keen interest in various aspects of music and plays the piano as a hobby. In 1996, he obliged a viewer who wrote into the ''Downtown Kazaana'' show requesting him to perform a piano piece.{{cite episode |series=Downtown Kazaana |title=Episode #38 |network=[[Asahi Broadcasting Corporation|ABC]] |date=3 February 1996}} Later, in 1999, [[Downtown (Owarai)|Downtown]] would challenge him to perform a piano concert late at night while being terrorized by jump scares.{{cite episode |series=[[Downtown no Gaki no Tsukai ya Arahende!!]] |title=#491 山崎邦正 深夜の廃校でひとりぼっちのピアノコンサートの刑!! |trans-title=#491 Yamazaki Hōsei's Solo Late-night School Piano Concert Punishment!! |network=[[Nippon TV|NTV]] |date=5 December 1999}} In 2011 Hōsei successfully completed a challenge to perform ''[[Étude Op. 10, No. 3 (Chopin)|Étude Op. 10, No. 3 by Chopin]]'' on a miniature toy piano.{{cite episode |series=Showbiz Arts Awards (ザ芸能界ウラ芸大賞) |network=[[Nippon TV|NTV]] |date=4 February 2011}} Composing is another hobby of his, an aspect heavily utilized within the '''Yamasaki Produce''' segments of [[Downtown no Gaki no Tsukai ya Arahende!!|Gaki no Tsukai]], where he creates both the music and lyrics for various songs which the rest of the cast must perform. Outside of this series, he also composed tracks for the debut single of ''AiAi'' in 2002. He greatly enjoys singing [[karaoke]] and has participated in a number of televised contests, most notably winning first place in the ''15th Comedian Karaoke King'' competition.{{cite episode |series=Comedian Karaoke King (歌うま王座) |network=[[Fuji Television|Fuji TV]] |date=30 July 2009}} On other programs he has also parodied many music artists such as [[Gackt]], [[Exile (Japanese band)|Exile]] and [[V6 (band)|V6]].{{cite web |url=http://www.ze.em-net.ne.jp/~hdk/monomane/ |script-title=ja:ものまね王座決定戦データベース |trans-title=Monomane Playoffs Database |access-date=30 June 2015 |language=Japanese}} In addition, Hōsei has taken dance classes with an instructor and once showed footage of him practicing to [[Lady Gaga]] music.{{cite episode |series=Meringue no Kimochi |network=[[Nippon TV|NTV]] |date=30 July 2011}} ===Impersonations=== Hōsei acts as an [[impersonator]] and has participated in many contests on this theme, such as '''Monomane Battle''' and '''[[Monomane Grand Prix]]''', where he mimicked other comedians such as [[Ayako Imoto]] or parodied characters on shows like [[Death Note]]. During impersonation segments of the [[Downtown no Gaki no Tsukai ya Arahende!!|Gaki no Tsukai]] No Laughing series he'll sometimes be called upon multiple times to incite laughter.{{cite episode |series=[[Downtown no Gaki no Tsukai ya Arahende!!]] |title=No Laughing in Yugawara |network=[[Nippon TV|NTV]] |date=2004}} Frequently Hōsei impersonates women such as the many popstars of the [[Shōwa period]],{{cite episode |series=[[Downtown no Gaki no Tsukai ya Arahende!!]] |title=#1068 Yamasaki's Shōwa Era Popular Song Hit Parade |network=[[Nippon TV|NTV]] |date=21 August 2011}} or acts in the role of fictional female characters such as the bride at a wedding.{{cite episode |series=[[Downtown no Gaki no Tsukai ya Arahende!!]] |title=#1248 Goodbye Tsukitei Hōsei |network=[[Nippon TV|NTV]] |date=29 March 2015}} In 2008 he won 6th place in a "Who is the most beautiful transvestite in showbiz" contest.{{cite web |url=http://www.tv-asahi.co.jp/otameshi/contents/bn/0017/ |title=Otameshi #17 Summary |access-date=30 June 2015 |language=Japanese}} When [[Masatoshi Hamada]] was chosen to cross-dress in the [[Downtown no Gaki no Tsukai ya Arahende!!|Gaki no Tsukai]] No Laughing series, he commented that, "Yamazaki should do this."{{cite episode |series=[[Downtown no Gaki no Tsukai ya Arahende!!]] |title=No-Laughing Airport |network=[[Nippon TV|NTV]] |date=31 December 2011}} ===English=== At one time Hōsei studied English for two years.{{cite episode |series=Nep League |script-title=ja:ネプリーグ |network=[[Fuji Television|Fuji TV]] |date=20 April 2009}} In 1999, Imada Koji mentioned that he, [[Ameagari Kesshitai]] and a junior visited Hōsei's home for English conversation practise.{{cite web |url=http://www.fujitv.co.jp/LOVELOVE/talk/136.html |title=#136 LOVE LOVE あいしてる |date=14 August 1999 |language=Japanese}} He has also chosen to sing the occasional song in English, such as ''[[Smoke Gets in Your Eyes#The Platters version|Smoke Gets in Your Eyes by The Platters]]'' which got a passing score in a karaoke contest.{{cite web |url=http://sp.natalie.mu/owarai/news/24800 |script-title=ja:"歌がうまい王座"全16回の歴代王者が参戦する究極王座開催 |trans-title=Song King Competing Champions |date=6 December 2009 |language=Japanese}} However the full extent of his present-day English proficiency is unknown. ===Miscellaneous=== After feeling a sense of anxiety from the highs and lows of the entertainment industry, Hōsei sought to expand his skill base and gain further qualifications to fall back on. As well as English and piano, he dabbled in various subjects such as computers and game creation to varying degrees of proficiency before settling into his [[rakugo]] studies.{{cite web |url=http://news.livedoor.com/article/detail/7505587/ |script-title=ja:山崎邦正が落語家に転身した狙い |trans-title=Yamazaki Hōsei Turns to Rakugo |date=16 March 2013 |website=livedoor NEWS |language=Japanese}} At the age of 32 he enrolled on an 8-year [[Psychology]] course at [[Rissho University]] but lost enthusiasm halfway through and dropped out.{{cite episode |series=Ametalk |script-title=ja:アメトーーク |network=[[TV Asahi]] |date=29 April 2010}} ==Suberi-kyara== ''Suberu'' literally means “to slip”, but in owarai lingo, ''subetta'' refers to a joke or gag that fails to grab any laughs or reaction. (''Kyara'', short for ''kyarakuta'' or character.)
Yamasaki's persona on the show (and in the owarai community in general) is of the unfunny underdog who tries very hard to be funny, but fails. His failure is always accentuated by a snide remark from one of the other members of the show. Though his jokes may be amusing, members will intentionally stifle their laughter to satisfy the running gag. ==Ijime-kyara== ''Ijimeru'' means to bully or pick on someone. Of all the members of ''Gaki no Tsukai'', Yamasaki takes the most physical abuse. The entire series, '''Yamasaki Vs. Moriman''', is based around a series of bizarre wrestling matches in which Yamasaki always loses to the larger and powerful Holstein Morio from the comedy duo, Moriman. The content of the matches changes with each battle, but past matches have found the two tossing hot cooking oil at one another, trying to force each other into a tub of blue [[kakigori]] syrup, and whacking one another with thick [[burdock]] roots. Every year since 2007 during the ''No Laughing'' New Years Specials, Yamasaki inevitably comes face to face with an irate [[Masahiro Chono]]; a pro-wrestler, and is slapped. ==Personal life== ===Family=== Hōsei's tearful marriage was broadcast on [[Downtown no Gaki no Tsukai ya Arahende!!|Gaki no Tsukai]] in 2001.{{cite episode |series=[[Downtown no Gaki no Tsukai ya Arahende!!]] |title=#583 山ちゃんのハッピー結婚式大上映会!! |trans-title=#583 Yamazaki's Happy Wedding Premier!! |network=[[Nippon TV|NTV]] |date=4 November 2001}} Aya Yamazaki would later feature in an episode highlighting her quirky answers to various questions.{{cite episode |series=[[Downtown no Gaki no Tsukai ya Arahende!!]] |title=#874 クイズ山崎あやの500のコトト |trans-title=#874 Aya Yamazaki 500 Questions |network=[[Nippon TV|NTV]] |date=14 October 2007}} He has two daughters named Rara-chan and Momo-chan.{{cite episode |series=[[Downtown no Gaki no Tsukai ya Arahende!!]] |title=No-Laughing Earth Defense Force |network=[[Nippon TV|NTV]] |date=31 December 2013}} On September 8, 2012 his son Tenma-kun was born, Hōsei has noted how his birthday matches [[Hitoshi Matsumoto]].{{cite episode |series=Downtown DX |network=[[Yomiuri Telecasting Corporation|YTV]] |date=13 February 2014}} ===Hobbies=== Hōsei enjoys [[mahjong]] and invited [[Hitoshi Matsumoto]] to play with him as part of his 20th anniversary special. As an avid reader he became addicted to the work of [[Keigo Higashino]].{{cite episode |series=Kaiketsu! Emi Channel |network=[[Kansai Telecasting Corporation|KTV]] |date=24 April 2015}} At one time he engaged in table tennis matches with junior entertainers at a local community center.{{cite web |url=http://www.tv-tokyo.co.jp/yarisugi/backnumber/071027/ |title=Yarisugi #127 Summary |date=27 October 2007 |website=TV Tokyo |language=Japanese}} He also notes jet-skiing as a hobby {{cite web |url=http://shogo2015.tumblr.com/ |title=Tsukitei Hōsei's Column for Shōgo Hamada |access-date=30 June 2015 |website=Tumblr |language=Japanese}} and enjoys watching American series such as [[Desperate Housewives]].{{cite web |url=https://twitter.com/tukiteihousei/status/587821720666406913 |script-title=ja:お薦めのアメリカドラマ教えて |date=13 April 2015 |language=Japanese |trans-title=Recommend me some American drama |website=Twitter}} As Hōsei travels around Japan performing [[rakugo]], he keeps a {{Nihongo|Japanese temple stamp book|go shuin chou}} to commemorate his visits.{{cite episode |script-title=ja:ほっとするわ |network=[[Kansai Telecasting Corporation|KTV]] |date=24 November 2014}} ==List of works== ===Regular television work=== {{columns-list|colwidth=30em| *''[[Downtown no Gaki no Tsukai ya Arahende!!]]'' ([[Nippon TV|NTV]] 1989–Present) *{{Nihongo|''Funky Monkey Teacher''|ファンキーモンキー寛平先生がゆく!}} ([[Asahi Broadcasting Corporation|ABC]] 1992–1994) *{{Nihongo|''Downtown Nari''|ダウンタウン也}} ([[Tokyo Broadcasting System|TBS]] 1993) *{{Nihongo|''Downtown Juice''|ダウンタウン汁}} ([[Tokyo Broadcasting System|TBS]] 1993–1994) *{{Nihongo|''Tenshi no U・B・U・G''|天使のU・B・U・G}} ([[Fuji Television|Fuji TV]] 1994–1995) *{{Nihongo|''Pokkapoka''|ぽっかぽか}} ([[Tokyo Broadcasting System|TBS]] 1994–1997) *{{Nihongo|''Downtown Kazaana''|かざあなダウンタウン}} ([[Asahi Broadcasting Corporation|ABC]] 1995–1996) *{{Nihongo|''Heisei Shimura Family''|平成志村ファミリー}} ([[Fuji Television|Fuji TV]] 1996–1997) *{{Nihongo|''Tensai Terebi-kun''|天才てれびくん}} ([[NHK]] 1998–2000) *{{Nihongo|''Drive A Go! Go!''|ドライブ A GO!GO!}} ([[TV Tokyo]] 2002–Present) *{{Nihongo|''Marco Polori!''|マルコポロリ!}} ([[Kansai Telecasting Corporation|KTV]] 2006–Present) *{{Nihongo|''Yamazaki Hōsei's 20th Anniversary Celebration''|祝山崎邦正20周年 ホンマは正月よりもめでたいでぇ！}} ([[Kansai Telecasting Corporation|KTV]] 2008) *{{Nihongo|''Warau Yōsei''|笑う妖精}} ([[TV Asahi]] 2009–2010) *{{Nihongo|''Yoshimoto Golden Biographies''|よしもと黄金列伝!}} ([[Yomiuri Telecasting Corporation|YTV]] 2012–Present) *{{Nihongo|''Osaka Lunch Time Chat Nanishiyo!?''|大阪発しゃべるランチタイム なにしよ!?}} ([[Television Osaka|TVO]] 2013–2014) *{{Nihongo|''Ameagari Yorozu Dō''|雨上がりよろず堂}} ([[Yomiuri Telecasting Corporation|YTV]] 2014) *{{Nihongo|''Osaka Honwaka TV''|大阪ほんわかテレビ}} ([[Yomiuri Telecasting Corporation|YTV]] 2015–Present) *{{Nihongo|''Kansai Information Net-ten!''|かんさい情報ネットten!}} ([[Yomiuri Telecasting Corporation|YTV]]) }} ===Television appearances=== {{columns-list|colwidth=30em| *''DAY BREAK'' ([[Chubu-Nippon Broadcasting|CBC]] 1989) *{{Nihongo|''Yoshimoto Village''|ビレッジ吉本}} ([[Tokyo Broadcasting System|TBS]] 1990) *{{Nihongo|''12th Rookie Comedian Grand Prix''|第12回 ABCお笑い新人グランプリ}} ([[Asahi Broadcasting Corporation|ABC]] 15 January 1991) *{{Nihongo|''Denpa Shōnen International ''|電波少年INTERNATIONAL}} ([[Nippon TV|NTV]] 1994–1998) *{{Nihongo|''Ametalk!''|アメトーーク!}} ([[TV Asahi]] 2003–Present) *{{Nihongo|''Messe''|メッセ弾}} ([[Television Osaka|TVO]] 2006–2009) *{{Nihongo|''Yarisugi Koji''|やりすぎコージー}} ([[TV Tokyo]] 2008–2010) *{{Nihongo|''VS. Arashi''|VS嵐}} ([[Fuji Television|Fuji TV]] 2010–2012 ''Episodes #97, 144 and 182'') *{{Nihongo|''Hitoshi Matsumoto no Marumaruna Hanashi''|人志松本の○○な話}} ([[Fuji Television|Fuji TV]]) *{{Nihongo|''Hitoshi Matsumoto no Suberanai Hanashi''|人志松本のすべらない話}} ([[Fuji Television|Fuji TV]]) *{{Nihongo|''Entertainer Rating Check''|芸能人格付けチェック}} ([[TV Asahi]]) *{{Nihongo|''Hamachanga!''|浜ちゃんが!}} ([[Yomiuri Telecasting Corporation|YTV]]) *{{Nihongo|''Downtown DX''|ダウンタウンDX}} ([[Yomiuri Telecasting Corporation|YTV]]) *{{Nihongo|''Maki Mizuno Magic Restaurant R''|水野真紀の魔法のレストランR}} ([[Mainichi Broadcasting System|MBS]]) *{{Nihongo|''Birdman Contest''|鳥人間コンテスト}} ([[Yomiuri Telecasting Corporation|YTV]] ''Commentator'') *{{Nihongo|''Tokumori! Yoshimoto''|特盛！よしもと}} ([[Yomiuri Telecasting Corporation|YTV]]) *{{Nihongo|''Kugizuke''|上沼・高田のクギズケ！}} ([[Yomiuri Telecasting Corporation|YTV]]) *{{Nihongo|''Uramayo''|ウラマヨ}} ([[Kansai Telecasting Corporation|KTV]]) *{{Nihongo|''Kaitetsu! Emi Channel''|快傑えみちゃんねる}} ([[Kansai Telecasting Corporation|KTV]]) }} ===Film & OVA=== {{columns-list|colwidth=30em| *{{Nihongo|''Pappakapā''|パッパカパー}} (1994) *''Chameleon'' (1996) *''Tears of Kitty'' (2007) *''TWILIGHT FILE X'' (2012) *NMB48's Kotani Riho vs Tsukitei Hōsei Hetare Taiketsu (19 June 2013, CD Bonus for [[Bokura no Eureka]]) *{{Nihongo|''Mentai Piriri 2''|めんたいぴりり2}} ([[Television Nishinippon Corporation|TNC]] 2015 ''Part 1'') }} ===Radio=== *{{Nihongo|''K'zStation Ore-tachi Yattemasu''|K'zStationオレたちやってま〜す}} ([[Mainichi Broadcasting System|MBS]] Internet Radio 2000–Present) *{{Nihongo|''Broadcasting Room of Hitoshi Matsumoto''|松本人志の放送室}} (Irregular Guest) ===Theater=== *{{Nihongo|''Lumine the Yoshimoto''|ルミネtheよしもと}} (Various) *{{Nihongo|''Yoshimoto New Comedy Troupe''|よしもと新喜劇}} (Various) *{{Nihongo|''Shinjuku Midnight Baby''|新宿ミッドナイトベイビー}} (2009) ===Music=== *{{Nihongo|''Yamazaki Ichiban!''|ヤマザキ一番！}} (27 May 1998, JAN: 4935228981052) *{{Nihongo|''AiAi - God of Youth''|AiAi 青神(青春の神様)}} (Composer, 6 March 2002, JAN: 4988008643633) ===Books=== *{{Nihongo|''Usagi Nakamura & Yamazaki Hōsei Consultation''|うさぎ・邦正の相談所}} (September 2005, {{ISBN|4479391223}}) *{{Nihongo|''Miracle''|奇跡}} (April 2008, {{ISBN|4860102576}}) *{{Nihongo|''Why I Became a Rakugo''|僕が落語家になった理由}} (25 January 2013, {{ISBN|4757221592}}) ==External links== * [http://search.yoshimoto.co.jp/talent_prf/?id=708 Yoshimoto Kogyo profile] {{ja icon}} * [https://twitter.com/tukiteihousei Official Twitter] {{ja icon}} * [https://ja-jp.facebook.com/tukitei.housei Official Facebook] {{ja icon}} * [http://hassyoutei.com/members/tsukitei-housei/ Rakugo group page] {{ja icon}} * {{IMDb name|2643785}} ==References== {{columns-list|colwidth=30em| {{Reflist}} }} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Tsukitei, Hosei}} [[Category:Japanese comedians]] [[Category:Rakugoka]] [[Category:People from Nishinomiya]] [[Category:1968 births]] [[Category:Living people]]

{{refimprove|date=January 2014}} {{Infobox film | name = Joy of Learning | image size = | image = Joy of Learning FilmPoster.jpeg | caption = The film's poster, bearing its French title. | director = [[Jean-Luc Godard]] | producer = | writer = [[Jean-Luc Godard]]
[[Jean-Jacques Rousseau]] | narrator = Jean-Luc Godard | starring = [[Juliet Berto]]
[[Jean-Pierre Léaud]] | music = | cinematography = Germaine Cohen | editing = | distributor = | released = 28 June 1969 | runtime = 95 minutes | country = France | language = French | budget = }} '''''Joy of Learning''''' ({{lang-fr|Le Gai savoir}}) is a [[1969 in film|1969 film]] by [[Jean-Luc Godard]].{{cite web|url=http://en.unifrance.org/movie/5551/joy-of-learning|title=Joy of Learning|publisher=unifrance.org|accessdate=2014-02-28}} The shooting started before the events of [[May 68]] and was finished shortly afterwards. Coproduced by the [[ORTF|O.R.T.F.]], the film was upon completion rejected by French national television, then released in the cinema where it was subsequently banned by the French government. The film was entered into the [[19th Berlin International Film Festival]].{{cite web |url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0062997/awards |title=IMDB.com: Awards for Joy of Learning |accessdate=2010-03-07 |work=imdb.com}} The title is a reference to [[Nietzsche]]'s ''[[The Gay Science]]''.{{cite book |last=Brody |first=Richard |title=Everything Is Cinema: The Working Life of Jean-Luc Godard |publisher=Metropolitan Books |year=2008 |isbn=978-0-8050-6886-3}} ==Plot== Patricia and Émile meet at night in the middle of nowhere. While reading, listening to the radio and discussing the information they are retrieving, they develop mutual beliefs. ==Cast== * [[Juliet Berto]] - Patricia Lumumba * [[Jean-Pierre Léaud]] - Emile Rousseau * [[Jean-Luc Godard]] - Narrator (voice) ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * {{IMDb title|id=0062997|title=Le Gai savoir}} {{Jean-Luc Godard}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Joy Of Learning}} [[Category:1969 films]] [[Category:French films]] [[Category:French-language films]] [[Category:1960s drama films]] [[Category:Films directed by Jean-Luc Godard]] [[Category:French black-and-white films]] [[Category:French avant-garde and experimental films]] [[Category:Non-narrative films]] {{1960s-France-film-stub}}

revision.comment: /* top */removing deprecated {{[[Template:Infobox musical artist|Infobox musical artist]]}} parameters ([[Wikipedia:Bots/Requests for approval/NihlusBOT 4|Task 4]])
revision.text:
{{COI|date=June 2017}} {{peacock|date=June 2017}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = Joyce Beetuan Koh | image = | caption = | image_size = | birth_name = Koh Bee Tuan | birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=yes|1968|6|9}} | birth_place = [[Singapore]] | death_date = | death_place = | origin = | background = non_performing_personnel | instrument = piano | genre = [[Contemporary classical music]] | occupation = Composer, educator, conductor | years_active = | label = | associated_acts = | website = {{URL|jbtkoh.net}} }}
'''Joyce Beetuan Koh''' (born June 9, 1968) is a Singaporean [[composer]], [[sound artist]], and [[educator]].
== Career == Koh studied composition at [[King's College London]] under the tutorship of [[David Lumsdaine]], and at [[University of York]] with [[Nicola Lefanu]], receiving a PhD in Composition in 1997. She received the [[Nadia Boulanger]] scholarship and studied in Paris with [[Brian Ferneyhough]] at Royaumont in 1995, [[Tristan Murail]] in 1996, and at [[IRCAM]] Cursus in Music Computing 1997-98 with [[Hans Tutschku]] and [[Mikhail Malt]]. <ref>{{cite web | url=http://jbtkoh.net | title=Joyce Beetuan Koh | work=Biography | publisher= jbtkoh.net | accessdate=2017-06-08}}</ref>. Koh was a composer-in-residence at the [[Herrenhaus Edenkoben]] in 2004. In 2007, Koh become a founding faculty member of the music department of [[School of the arts, Singapore]], and then became Vice-Dean ([[interdisciplinary studies]]) at the [[Nanyang Academy of Fine Arts]] in 2010. Koh is a founding member of the Composers' Society of Singapore and served as its President 2013-16. <ref>{{cite web | url=https://composers.sg/profile/joyce-koh-bee-tuan/ | title=Joyce Koh Bee Tuan | work= Member webpage | publisher= Composer Society of Singapore | accessdate=2017-06-08}}</ref>
=== Honours === * Koh received the [[Young Artist Award]] from the [[National Arts Council (Singapore)|National Arts Council]], Singapore, in the category for music, for her orchestra works TAI, commissioned by [[Singapore Symphony Orchestra]]. <ref name=NAC Young Artist Award>{{cite web | url=https://www.nac.gov.sg/singaporeartsscene/youngArtistAward/overview.html | title = Laureates of the Artist Awards | publisher = National Arts Council, Singapore | accessdate=2017-06-08}}</ref>
== Creative work == === Collaborations === Koh’s music has been performed by [[BBC Symphony Orchestra]], Hungarian Radio [[Budapest Symphony Orchestra]], [[Stavanger Symphony Orchestra]], [[Singapore Symphony Orchestra]], Résonance Contemporaine, The Song Company of Australia, [[Nieuw Ensemble]], Take 5, and Reconsil, as well as by soloists including [Prodromos Symeonidis]], [[Frode Haltli]], and [[Thalia Myers]]. Her compositions for dance include a series of works with The Arts Fission Company, for example ‘In the Name of Red’ (2015), a site-specific work for the inauguration festival of the [[National Gallery Singapore]]). Leaning on her concept of multimedia performance as a "theatre of music", Koh created Away We Go (2015) together with [[Étienne Turpin]], commissioned by [[NTU Centre of Contemporary Art]]), and On the String (2010), commissioned by [[Singapore Arts Festival]]). She co-created the interactive sound installation The Canopy (2010-13), presented at [[World Stage Design Festival]] (UK 2013) and [[International Computer Music Conference]] (UK 2011). Koh collaborated with theatre director [[Steve Dixon (actor)|Steve Dixon]] on adapting [[T. S. Eliot]]'s ''[[The Waste Land]]'' in a one-actor piece with video and electroacoustic sound. <ref>Koh JBT & Dixon S (2014), {{cite web | url=http://econtact.ca/16_2/koh-dixon_wasteland.html/ | title= The Music of T.S. Eliot’s Poetry: Integrating text, live performance, sound design and video in a multimedia theatre production of 'The Waste Land' | accessdate=2017-06-09}}, Canadian Electroacoustic Community (CEC), eContact 16.2</ref>
=== Compositional style === Koh learned the piano from an early age. Her fascination for resonating strings in particular and sonic timbre in general led to taking up music professionally, coming to think of composition as a form of ‘calligraphy on a sonic canvas’. Through computer-assisted composition and audio processing, she could imagine sounds beyond those produced by acoustic instruments, and sonic space. She developed a concept of "theatre of music", where the sonic canvas became physical, i.e., the stage. That is, "whilst the narrative structure of the composition may be based on theatrical devices, the sound objects (effectively the play’s characters) are driven by musical identities and relationships". <ref>Loh J & Haykal B (editors), (2014). Latitudes and Attitudes, Exhibition Catalogue, ICA LaSalle, {{ISBN|978-981-07-9067-7}}, p. 54</ref> <ref>Haykal B (2014), {{cite web | url=http://econtact.ca/16_2/haykal_koh.html | title= Letting Time and Sound Pass: Interview with Singaporean composer Joyce Beetuan Koh | accessdate=2017-06-09}}, Canadian Electroacoustic Community (CEC), eContact 16.2</ref> Koh’s work often starts with an external structure from architecture, calligraphy, or science. The 2010 multimedia performance ‘On the String’ is a consolidation of this approach. Asking herself: “What if we could hear the sounds of vibrating one-dimensional strings? Or the sonic texture created by various vibration patterns of a string curving space? If these imaginings were audible, what would they sound like?” Composition becomes a "systematic musicalisation of certain features of the scientific thought and, through interdisciplinary investigations (music, visual arts, interactive design, instrument design, light), culminates in a multimedia performance". <ref name = "Koh & Lindborg 2010">{{cite web | url=http://permagnus.org/pm/research/projects/OTS/index.html | author = Koh, Joyce & Lindborg, PerMagnus | title=On the String (web documentation of the creative process) | publisher=permagnus.org | accessdate=2017-06-08}}</ref>
=== Selected compositions === ==== Orchestra ==== * TAI (1997) * Granite Harbour (1995)
==== Chamber music ==== * Fingerprints for octet (2015) * Piano Peals (2006) * Edenkobener Beethoven Bagatellen (2005) * les pierres magenta for piano and ensemble (2002) * la pierre magenta for piano (2001)
==== Works for stage and dance ==== * In the name of red (2015) * The Waste Land (2013) * Locust Wrath (2013) * On the String (2010) * 16 Wege das Nein zu vermeiden (2005)
==== Multimedia ==== * Shape of a City (2015) * Hearing Lines (2013)
=== Discography === * Edenkobener Beethoven Bagatellen (2005, with [[BeeperDesign]]) * Piano Peals (2004, with [[ABRSM]])
== References == {{reflist}}
== External links == *{{Official website|jbtkoh.net}}
{{Authority control}}

revision.text:
'''Kaunas Dance Theatre Aura''' is the professional theatre of modern dance in [[Kaunas]], [[Lithuania]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://kauno.diena.lt/dienrastis/kita/po-soko-kaune-sokio-kontaktai-tel-avive-33320|title=Po šoko Kaune - šokio kontaktai Tel Avive|last=KUZMICKAITĖ |first=Jūratė |date= 2005-12-03|work= [[Kauno Diena]]|language=Lithuanian|accessdate=2009-10-26|location=Kaunas }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://kauno.diena.lt/dienrastis/kita/jausminis-gyvenimo-pojutis-2593|title=Jausminis gyvenimo pojūtis Kūrybinės veiklos dvidešimtmetį minintis šokio teatras “Aura” savo žiūrovus pasveikino festivaliu |last=VAITIEKŪNAITĖ |first=Ramutė |date=2002-10-04 |accessdate=2009-10-26|location=Kaunas}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.balsas.lt/naujiena/250410/aura-soks-rheinsbergo-pilies-teatro-scenoje/rubrika:naujienos-laisvalaikis-dartruksta|title=„Aura“ šoks Rheinsbergo Pilies teatro scenoje|date=2009-04-30 |work=Balsas|language=Lithuanian|accessdate=2009-10-26}}</ref>
==History ==
A group of modern dance was founded in 1980 by [[Birutė Letukaitė]] and several other young dancers. In 1982 they gave their first performance. Under the leadership of B. Letukaite who remains Aura’s managing and artistic director this small group of dancers has grown into and has become the best known and most decorated modern/contemporary dance company in Lithuania. In 1995 the City of Kaunas awarded Kaunas Dance theatre Aura the status of a municipal theatre that so far no other dance troupe in the country managed to achieve yet.
Since 1989 Kaunas Dance theatre Aura is the organizer of the International Modern Dance Festival. Though the International Modern Dance Festival is first of all an integral part of cultural life and a meaningful tradition in Kaunas, the Festival is being brought to other Lithuanian towns too. The unique feature of the Festival is the night performances shown at alternative spaces in Kaunas.
==References== {{Reflist}}
== External links== *{{Official website|http://www.aura.lt/main.php/id/1}} {{lt icon}}

{{Infobox video game |title = Knights of Honor |image = Knights of Honor Coverart.png |developer = [[Black Sea Studios]] |publisher = {{Video game release|EU|[[Sunflowers Interactive]]|NA|[[Paradox Interactive]]|AU|[[Atari, Inc. (Atari, SA subsidiary)|Atari, Inc.]]}} |designer = Vesselin Handjiev |programmer = Panayot Vaniozdravov Yanazov |artist = Rossen Manchev |composer = Borislav Slavov Glorian |engine = |released = {{Video game release|EU|September 30, 2004|NA|May 10, 2005|AU|August 3, 2005}} |genre = [[Real-time strategy]] |modes = [[Single-player video game|Single-player]], [[Multiplayer video game|multiplayer]] |platforms = [[Microsoft Windows]] }}
'''''Knights of Honor''''' is a [[real-time strategy]] (RTS) game developed by [[Bulgaria]]n [[Black Sea Studios]]. It was published by [[Sunflowers Interactive]] in Europe in 2004 and [[Paradox Entertainment]] in North America in 2005. The game takes place in [[Middle Ages|Medieval Europe]], spanning the early centuries of the second millennium in three historical time periods. The player can choose to play as one of over 100 playable kingdoms.
==Gameplay== ''Knights of Honor'' is played on a large map of Europe spanning from Ireland to [[Armenia]] and from Scandinavia to the northern coast of Africa. The map is divided into parcels of land called provinces. Each province is governed by a city and contains several "Rural Areas" which can be towns, farms, monasteries and coast towns. These rural areas can't be altered and are placed randomly across the map before each game. The city, however has room for several buildings which can give bonuses to the rural areas or the city itself, such as more piety in the monasteries when a church is built or a higher income from the towns when a market is present in the city. Other buildings are needed to recruit certain units (such as a swordsmith for sword-wielding units or a fletcher for bow-wielding units) or to defend the city such as walls and towers. A city only has limited room for buildings. Thus, not all buildings can be built in a city and the player must carefully consider what to build for a particular city. Compared to other strategy games, building structures in ''KOH'' takes a rather long time. The main goal of the game is to become emperor of Europe. However, the player is free to do whatever they wish. There is no set time limit.
===Resources=== There are three kinds of resources which can be spent on a variety of upgrades. Money is needed to recruits units, build buildings, etc. It is earned by taxes, trading and kingdom power. Piety is used for increasing your kingdom power and converting provinces to your religion. Books are used to educate your knights and adopting provinces. Towns themselves also generate hammers (used to construct certain buildings) and food which determines how long they can withstand sieges.
===Religion=== Religion plays an important role in Knights of Honor. There are 4 different types of religion: The Catholic Church, The Orthodox Church, Islam, and Paganism. The catholic Pope has much influence in medieval Europe. He can excommunicate catholic kingdoms and call for crusades against non-catholic kingdoms. When a player chooses to go on a crusade they are granted powerful Crusader units. When the Pope dies, his successor is chosen among several clerics throughout Europe. If the player happens to have a very experienced cleric, there is a chance he will be chosen as Pope. From then on, the player controls the Pope and can choose to excommunicate kingdoms and call for crusades, a successful crusade can result in a puppet state that is unquestionably loyal to the leader of the crusade or plunder the town for a huge sum of gold. The Catholic Church is located in Western Europe and the Mediterranean. Orthodox factions are located in south east Europe and answer to Byzantium. These factions can declare independence and form their own churches which grants them a greater sum of gold while lacking the disadvantage of being excommunicated which results in a gold penalty. Islamic empires have the ability to call a Jihad which is similar to a Crusade and will cause armies to spawn at their borders and attack any invaders or rebels. This is a powerful ability but it has a long cool down period . Islam is found in north Africa and the middle east. Paganism is the smallest religion being found only in Scandinavia and some parts of eastern Europe. Pagans do not collect piety (a religious resource used to build certain units and buildings and perform some diplomatic options) so are free to focus on gold and are not troubled by religious problems such as religious tension but they have a penalty on their income and have bad relations with all other religions. Paganism is the only religion the player or other kingdoms cannot convert to, the only way to play as a pagan nation is to start the game as one. The player can renounce his faith and adopt another official religion (except paganism) but such religious conflict will often split the kingdom up and one must reunify the nations as a result.
===Trade and exotic goods=== Provinces can have up to three attributes called "''province features''" which allow the construction of certain buildings. For instance if a province contains fertile soil, an [[apiary]] can be built in that province. These buildings give access to "''trade goods''" which have a number of positive effects on the kingdom. For example, horses allows mounted units, wine makes a population happier and silver brings in extra money. Controlling such provinces is the key to success in ''Knights of Honor''. Besides trade goods, which can be obtained in provinces where the right province features are present or by importing them from other kingdoms, there is another type of goods called "''exotic goods''". These goods can't be produced within a province but have to be imported by means of an [[admiralty]], the upgraded version of a [[harbour]]. Examples are [[ivory]], [[Gemstone|gems]] and [[spice]]s. Exotic goods, together with trade goods, are needed to activate so called "''kingdom advantages''". There are ten different kingdom advantages each requiring a different set of trade and exotic goods and each giving a different advantage. For instance, the kingdom advantage "''Secret Order''", which gives a bonus to spies, requires the following trade goods: [[column]]s, statues, silver and [[dye]]s and the following exotic goods: [[ebony]] and [[ivory]].
Controlling many provinces certainly gives an advantage over other kingdoms not only because of more income but also because of the goods and eventually the kingdom advantages. However, larger kingdoms are harder to maintain and defend.
==Modding==
A large community of modders created a lot of content for the game, though nowadays almost all has been lost in the closure of Sunflowers/Black Sea Studios Website. But some mods have been restored and have been recently developed thanks to the nostalgia of some players. One of them has created a mod which allow to play on new monitor resolution such as Full HD - 1920x1080 and 1366x768p. It adds many new content and tweaks. <ref>{{cite web |language=en |title= Ultimate Edition - HD Patch & Overhaul (EN/FR/DE) mod for Knights of Honor |url= http://www.moddb.com/mods/knights-of-honor-ultimate-mod |website=Mod DB |accessdate=2017-03-05}}</ref>
==References== <references/>
==External links== *{{moby game|id=/knights-of-honor|name=''Knights of Honor''}}

style="width:075px;"|'''Year''' ! style="width:200px;"|'''Name''' ! style="width:200px;"|'''Film''' ! style="width:080px;"|'''Status''' ! style="width:650px;"|'''[[wikt:milestone|Milestone]]''' |- | 2007 | [[Marjane Satrapi]] | ''[[Persepolis (film)|Persepolis]]'' | {{nom}} | Shared nomination with [[Vincent Paronnaud]] |- |} ==Best Foreign Language Film== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center" |- style="background:#bfd7ff;" | colspan="6" style="text-align:center;"| '''[[Academy Award for Best Foreign Language Film|Foreign Language Film]]''' |- style="background:#ebf5ff;" ! page.title: List of apocalyptic and post-apocalyptic fiction

revision.comment: /* Works of apocalyptic and post-apocalyptic fiction */
revision.text:
{{distinguish|List of dystopian films}} {{More citations needed|date=November 2008}} <!-- On August 1, 2011, Stephen Ferg restructured the entire page into sortable columns, after considerable discussion on the Talk page. --> This is a '''list of apocalyptic and post-apocalyptic fiction''' works as portrayed in literature, film, television, and, comics.<ref>{{cite book|last=Brians|first=Paul|title=Nuclear holocausts : atomic war in fiction, 1895-1984|year=1987|publisher=Kent State University Press|location=Kent, Ohio|isbn=978-0-87338-335-6 |chapter=Nuclear Holocausts Bibliography}} ([http://public.wsu.edu/~brians/nuclear/a.htm Also online] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111227012854/http://public.wsu.edu/~brians/nuclear/a.htm |date=2011-12-27 }})</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Booker|first=M. Keith|last2=Thoma |first2=Anne-Marie|title=The science fiction handbook|year=2009|publisher=Wiley-Blackwell Pub.|location=Chichester, UK|isbn=978-1-4051-6205-0|pages=53–64}} Includes a list of notable works.</ref>
[[apocalyptic and post-apocalyptic fiction|Apocalyptic fiction]] is a [[subgenre]] of [[science fiction]] that is concerned with the [[Risks to civilization, humans and planet Earth|end of civilization]] due to a potentially [[existential risk|existential catastrophe]] such as [[nuclear warfare]], [[pandemic]], [[alien invasion|extraterrestrial attack]], [[impact event]], [[cybernetic revolt]], [[technological singularity]], [[dysgenics]], [[supernatural phenomena]], [[Eschatology|divine judgment]], [[climate change]], [[resource depletion]] or some other [[disaster|general disaster]]. [[apocalyptic and post-apocalyptic fiction|Post-apocalyptic fiction]] is set in a world or civilization after such a disaster. The time frame may be immediately after the catastrophe, focusing on the travails or psychology of survivors, or considerably later, often including the theme that the existence of pre-catastrophe civilization has been forgotten (or mythologized).
''[[Apocalypse]]'' is a Greek word referring to the end of the world. [[Apocalypticism]] is the religious belief that there will be an apocalypse, a term which originally referred to a revelation of God's will, but now usually refers to belief that the world will come to an end very soon, even within one's own lifetime.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/Apocalypticism |title=Dictionary-Apocalypticism |accessdate=2011-11-27}}</ref>
Apocalyptic fiction does not portray catastrophes, or disasters, or near-disasters that do not result in apocalypse. A ''threat'' of an apocalypse does not make a piece of fiction apocalyptic. For example, ''[[Armageddon (1998 film)|Armageddon]]'' and ''[[Deep Impact (film)|Deep Impact]]'' are considered [[disaster film]]s and not apocalyptic fiction because, although earth and/or human-kind are terribly threatened, in the end they manage to avoid destruction. Apocalyptic fiction is not the same as fiction that provides visions of a [[dystopian]] future. George Orwell's ''[[Nineteen Eighty-Four]]'', for example, is [[dystopian fiction]], not apocalyptic fiction.
==Works of apocalyptic and post-apocalyptic fiction== {{Dynamic list}} <!-- The works are entered roughly by year. If you add an entry, please try to put it into the right place by year. Thanks! --> {| class="wikitable sortable" |- !|Format !|Year !|Cause !|Title !|Author and notes |- style="vertical-align:top;" <!--format-->|TV series (Season) <!--year -->|2018-2019 <!--cause -->|War, supernatural <!--title -->|''[[American Horror Story: Apocalypse]]'' <!--desc -->|This is 8th season of [[American Horror Story]]. |- style="vertical-align:top;" <!--format-->|Film <!--year -->|1977 <!--cause -->|Eco, supernatural <!--title -->|''[[Holocaust 2000]]'' <!--desc -->|Directed by [[Alberto De Martino]]. |- style="vertical-align:top;" <!--format-->|Film <!--year -->|2014 <!--cause -->|Eco, technology <!--title -->|''[[Snowpiercer]]'' <!--desc -->|Takes place [[Alternative history|alternative 2014]] were an attempt to counteract [[global warming]] through [[climate engineering]] backfires catastrophically, causing an ice age and extinguishing nearly all life; only animals that can adapt to sub-zero temperatures and the inhabitants of Snowpiercer remain. |- style="vertical-align:top;" <!--format-->|Game <!--year -->|2016 <!--cause -->|Other <!--title -->|[[Nuclear Throne]] <!--desc -->|A post-apocalyptic shoot-e'm up by [[Vlambeer]], where humanity mutated into horrible monsters. These mutants are looking for the fabled Nuclear Throne. |- style="vertical-align:top;" <!--format-->|Radio <!--year -->|1938, 1943 <!--cause -->|Eco <!--title -->|''[[Lights Out (radio show)|Oxychloride X]]'' <!--desc -->|An episode of [[Arch Oboler]]'s popular 1930s and '40s radio horror and mystery anthology serial, ''[[Lights Out (radio show)|Lights Out]]''. A [[mental illness|deranged]] university chemistry student creates what turns out to be an "super-dissolving substance", with the potential, among other uses, to become "a [[Doomsday device|doomsday chemical superweapon]]". |- style="vertical-align:top;" <!--format-->|Animated <!--year -->|2017 <!--cause -->|Bioterrorism, zombies <!--title -->|''[[Resident Evil: Vendetta]]'' <!--desc -->|The story is set in between the events of Resident Evil 6 and Resident Evil 7: Biohazard. BSAA agent Chris Redfield is tracking Glenn Arias, a Brazilian-American death merchant and a former CIA operative who is wanted by both the Interpol and FBI. |- style="vertical-align:top;" <!--format-->|Game <!--year -->|2017 <!--cause -->|Technology, war <!--title -->|''[[Horizon Zero Dawn]]'' <!--desc -->|The story is set in the 31st century, in a world where humans have regressed to primitive tribal societies as a result of some unspecified calamity. Their technologically advanced predecessors are vaguely remembered as the "Old Ones." Large robotic creatures known merely as "machines" now dominate the Earth. |- style="vertical-align:top;" <!--format-->|Radio <!--year -->|1972 <!--cause -->|Aliens, disease, zombies <!--title -->|''[[WSWT|The Peoria Plague]]'' <!--desc -->|Originally recorded and aired by station WUHN (now [[WSWT]]), in [[Peoria, Illinois]]<ref>{{cite web|title=The Peoria Plague - Vintage Zombie Audio Drama (1972)|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hXt0GEave-s|website=YouTube|accessdate=20 June 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=The Peoria Plague|url=https://archive.org/details/ThePeoriaPlague|website=The Internet Archive|accessdate=20 June 2016}}</ref> |- style="vertical-align:top;" <!--format-->|Television <!--year -->|1982 <!--cause -->|War <!--title -->|''[[World War III (miniseries)|World War III]]'' <!--desc -->|Originally broadcast on the [[NBC]] television network. The film's original director, [[Boris Sagal]], died in a freak mishap during filming, and was replaced by his successor, [[David Greene (director)|David Greene]]. The teleplay was written by [[Robert L. Joseph]]. |- style="vertical-align:top;" <!--format-->|Game <!--year -->|1980 <!--cause -->|War <!--title -->|''[[Missile Command]]'' <!--desc -->|Arcade video game designed by [[Dave Theurer]] and developed by [[Atari, Inc.]] Later ported to many different [[home computing]] and gaming platforms, for many years afterward. Considered one of the most notable classic video games of all time. |- style="vertical-align:top;" <!--format-->|Film <!--year -->|1959 <!--cause -->|Eco, monsters <!--title -->|''[[The Giant Behemoth]]'' <!--desc -->|<ref>{{cite web|title=The Giant Behemoth (1959)|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0052611/|website=IMDb.com|accessdate=7 March 2016}}</ref> |- style="vertical-align:top;" <!--format-->|Film <!--year -->|2014 <!--cause -->|Disease <!--title -->|''[[Dawn of the Planet of the Apes]]'' <!--desc -->|Directed by [[Matt Reeves]], and based on characters created by Rick Jaffa and Amanda Silver (premise suggested by ''[[Planet of the Apes (novel)|Planet of the Apes]]'' by [[Pierre Boulle]]). A growing nation of genetically evolved apes is threatened by a band of human survivors of a devastating virus unleashed a decade earlier.<ref>{{cite web|title=Dawn of the Planet of the Apes (2014)|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt2103281/|website=IMDb.com|accessdate=9 February 2016}}</ref> |- style="vertical-align:top;" <!--format-->|Game <!--year -->|2012 <!--cause -->|Disease <!--title -->|''[[Zero Escape: Virtue's Last Reward]]'' <!--desc -->|Visual novel adventure game released for Nintendo 3DS and PlayStation Vita. The game takes place 45 years in the future, after a calamitous virus outbreak, known as Radical-6, has exterminated almost the entire human civilization. |- style="vertical-align:top;" <!--format-->|Radio <!--year -->|1951 <!--cause -->|War <!--title -->|''The Last Objective'' <!--desc -->|Written by [[Paul Carter (writer)|Paul Carter]] and adapted by [[Ernest Kinoy]] for [[NBC Red Network|NBC Radio]]'s 1950-51 sci-fi anthology series, ''[[Dimension X (radio program)|Dimension X]]''. A military android questions its continued existence, after the last of its human comrade-counterparts dies out from the effects of [[Chemical warfare|a mysterious doomsday super-weapon]] that was unleashed at the end of a generations-long global atomic war. |- style="vertical-align:top;" <!--format-->|Novel <!--year -->|1970 <!--cause -->|Supernatural, war, eco, human decline <!--title -->|''[[The Late, Great Planet Earth]]'' <!--desc -->|Bestselling blockbuster [[Bible prophecy]]-based "mockumentary" novel, co-written by [[Hal Lindsey]] and Carole Carlson, and later adapted into a 1979 feature-length theatrical motion picture narrated by [[Orson Welles]] |- style="vertical-align:top;" <!--format-->|Game <!--year -->|1992 <!--cause -->|Sun, aliens <!--title -->|''[[Epic (video game)|Epic]]'', and its 1994 follow-up sequel ''[[Inferno (video game)|Inferno]]'' <!--desc -->|Published by [[Ocean Software]] (now [[Atari, SA|Atari]]). A ''[[Battlestar Galactica (1978 TV series)|Battlestar Galactica]]''-esque 3-D space shooter video game for MS-DOS and other contemporary (at that time) [[personal computer|personal computing]] platforms. |- style="vertical-align:top;" <!--format-->|Game <!--year -->|1980 <!--cause -->|War <!--title -->|''[[NukeWar]]'' <!--desc -->|Published by gaming company [[Avalon Hill]]. A [[turn-based strategy]] game for many early [[Home computers|home computing platforms]], such as the [[Apple II]], the [[Commodore 64]], and the [[Atari 8-bit family|Atari 400/800]] model home computers. |- style="vertical-align:top;" <!--format-->|Television <!--year -->|1975-1977 <!--cause -->|Eco (nuclear waste explosion on the moon, followed by earthquakes, tsunamis, floods, etc. on Earth, caused by loss of the moon) <!--title -->|''[[Space: 1999]]'' <!--desc -->|Created by [[Gerry Anderson]] and wife [[Sylvia Anderson]] |- style="vertical-align:top;" <!--format-->|Radio <!--year -->|1946 <!--cause -->|War <!--title -->|''[[The Fifth Horsemen (radio play)|The Fifth Horseman]]'' <!--desc -->|Early (post-[[World War II]]) radio docudrama series originally aired over the now-defunct [[NBC Red Network|NBC Radio]] network. This "rare and unusual" series of shows (featuring many top Hollywood film performers of that era) was written, produced, and directed by [[Arnold Marquis (radio producer)|Arnold Marquis]], as part of a special postwar campaign aimed at convincing the public to place the then-newly developed technologies of nuclear energy and weaponry under [[United Nations]] control.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://archive.org/details/The_Fifth_Horseman|title=The Fifth Horseman|work=Internet Archive}}</ref> |- style="vertical-align:top;" <!--format-->|Game <!--year -->|2006 <!--cause -->|War <!--title -->|''[[DEFCON (video game)|DEFCON]]'' <!--desc -->|Created by independent British game developer [[Introversion Software]], and inspired (in part) by the 1983 film ''[[WarGames]]'' |- style="vertical-align:top;" <!--format-->|Television <!--year -->|1984 <!--cause -->|War <!--title -->|''[[Countdown to Looking Glass]]'' <!--desc -->|Canadian-produced TV movie, directed by producer Fred Barzyk, and originally premiering in the United States, on the [[HBO]] pay-[[cable TV]] network. |- style="vertical-align:top;" <!--format-->|Television <!--year -->|1994 <!--cause -->|Aliens, impact event <!--title -->|''[[Without Warning (1994 film)|Without Warning]]'' <!--desc -->|Directed by [[Robert Iscove]], and originally broadcast over the [[CBS]] television network |- style="vertical-align:top;" <!--format-->|Game <!--year -->|1998 <!--cause -->|Aliens, technology (cyber-terrorism) <!--title -->|''Red Baron 2573'' <!--desc -->|<ref>{{cite web|title=Red Baron 2573 (1998)|url=https://archive.org/details/RedBaron2573|website=The Internet Archive|publisher=Adam Stanchos|accessdate=28 January 2015}}</ref> |- style="vertical-align:top;" <!--format-->|Novel <!--year -->|1950 <!--cause -->|War <!--title -->|''[[Shadow on the Hearth]]'' <!--desc -->|[[Judith Merril]]; later [[Atomic Attack|adapted for television]] in 1954 |- style="vertical-align:top;" <!--format-->|Game <!--year -->|1992 <!--cause -->|Aliens, eco <!--title -->|''[[Galactix]]'' <!--desc -->|Backstory (featuring a [[satirical]] fake TV news story regarding the final depletion of the [[Amazon rain forest]]) and game play take place in the year 2019, in which a powerful alien attack force threatens to obliterate the Earth. Developed by Scott Host, for Cygnus Games (now [[Mountain King Studios]]).<ref>{{cite web|title=Galactix: Cygnus Software|url=https://archive.org/details/Galactix_746|website=The Internet Archive|accessdate=30 June 2016}}</ref> |- style="vertical-align:top;" <!--format-->|Game <!--year -->|2014 <!--cause -->|Impact event <!--title -->|''[[Ace Combat Infinity]]'' <!--desc -->|[[PlayStation 3]] online game depicting a new world war 20 years after a meteor strike hits much of the Earth's surface |- style="vertical-align:top;" <!--format-->|Game <!--year -->|2013 <!--cause -->|Disease, monsters <!--title -->|''[[The Last of Us]]'' <!--desc -->|A fungal spore infection turns most of humanity into monsters and a small band of survivors try to live on. |- style="vertical-align:top;" <!--format-->|Film <!--year -->|2013 <!--cause -->|Eco <!--title -->|''[[The Colony (2013 film)|The Colony]]'' <!--desc -->|Another ice age causes survivors to move underground. |- style="vertical-align:top;" <!--format-->|Television <!--year -->|2012–2014 <!--cause -->|Technology collapse <!--title -->|''[[Revolution (TV series)|Revolution]]'' <!--desc -->|All technology ceases after a global blackout. |- style="vertical-align:top;" <!--format-->|Novel <!--year -->|1964 <!--cause -->|Disease <!--title -->|''[[Virus (novel)|Virus]]'' <!--desc -->|Novel by [[Sakyo Komatsu]] about a lethal supergerm that kills humanity in months; later adapted into a [[Virus (1980 film)|1980 movie]] |- style="vertical-align:top;" <!--format-->|Novel <!--year -->|2008 <!--cause -->|Eco <!--title -->|''[[Flood (Baxter novel)|Flood]]'' <!--desc -->|The Earth is gradually submerged due to seismic activity that brings more water to the surface. |- style="vertical-align:top;" <!--format-->|Novel <!--year -->|2011 <!--cause -->|Technology <!--title -->|''[[Wool (series)|Wool]]'' <!--desc -->|A multi-part series by author [[Hugh Howey]] |- style="vertical-align:top;" <!--format-->|Novel <!--year -->|2008 <!--cause -->|War <!--title -->|''[[The Diamond of Darkhold]]'' <!--desc -->|The fourth book in [[Jeanne DuPrau]]'s ''[[City of Ember]]'' series |- style="vertical-align:top;" <!--format-->|Novel <!--year -->|2006 <!--cause -->|War <!--title -->|''[[The Prophet of Yonwood]]'' <!--desc -->|The third book in [[Jeanne DuPrau]]'s ''[[City of Ember]]'' series |- style="vertical-align:top;" <!--format-->|Play <!--year -->|2005 <!--cause -->| War and gang violence <!--title -->|''[[Mercury Fur]]'' <!--desc -->|[[Philip Ridley]] |- style="vertical-align:top;" <!--format-->|Novel <!--year -->|2004 <!--cause -->|War <!--title -->|''[[The People of Sparks]]'' <!--desc -->|The second book in [[Jeanne DuPrau]]'s ''[[City of Ember]]'' series. |- style="vertical-align:top;" <!--format-->|Novel <!--year -->|2000 <!--cause -->|Eco <!--title -->|''[[The Last Book in the Universe]]'' <!--desc -->|[[Rodman Philbrick]] |- style="vertical-align:top;" <!--format-->|Story <!--year -->|2001 <!--cause -->|War <!--title -->|"Autobahn nach Poznan" <!--desc -->|[[Andrzej Ziemianski]] |- style="vertical-align:top;" <!--format-->|Story <!--year -->|1950 <!--cause -->|War <!--title -->|"Dear Devil" <!--desc -->|[[Eric Frank Russell]] |- style="vertical-align:top;" <!--format-->|Story <!--year -->|1969 <!--cause -->|War <!--title -->|"[[A Boy and His Dog]]" <!--desc -->|[[Harlan Ellison]]; filmed in 1975 |- style="vertical-align:top;" <!--format-->|Story <!--year -->|1984 <!--cause -->|War <!--title -->|"Extinction is Forever" <!--desc -->|[[Louise Lawrence]] - A scientist uses a [[time travel|time machine]] to travel to the future and film the results of a nuclear war in a bid to prevent it from happening. However, his actions could have serious repercussions for the mutated descendants of the human race. |- style="vertical-align:top;" <!--format-->|Novel <!--year -->|1990 <!--cause -->|Divine prophecy <!--title -->|''[[Good Omens]]'' <!--desc -->|[[Neil Gaiman]] and [[Terry Pratchett]] |- style="vertical-align:top;" <!--format-->|Story <!--year -->|1949 <!--cause -->|War <!--title -->|"Let the Ants Try" <!--desc -->|[[Frederik Pohl]] under the [[pseudonym]] [[James MacCreigh]] |- style="vertical-align:top;" <!--format-->|Play <!--year -->|1942 <!--cause -->|War (also ice age and flood) <!--title -->|''[[The Skin of Our Teeth]]'' <!--desc -->|[[Thornton Wilder]] |- style="vertical-align:top;" <!--format-->|Novel <!--year -->|1922 <!--cause -->|War <!--title -->|''Theodore Savage'' (vt. Lest Ye Die) <!--desc -->|[[Cicely Hamilton]] <ref>[[E. F. Bleiler]] and [[Richard Bleiler]]. ''Science-Fiction: The Early Years''. Kent State University Press, 1990. (p.331). {{ISBN|9780873384162}}.</ref> |- style="vertical-align:top;" <!--format-->|Story <!--year -->|1941 <!--cause -->|War <!--title -->|"[[Magic City (story)|Magic City]]" <!--desc -->|[[Nelson S. Bond]] |- style="vertical-align:top;" <!--format-->|Story <!--year -->|1953 <!--cause -->|War <!--title -->|"[[Second Variety]]" <!--desc -->|[[Philip K. Dick]] |- style="vertical-align:top;" <!--format-->|Story <!--year -->|1949 <!--cause -->|War <!--title -->|"Time to Rest" <!--desc -->|[[John Wyndham]] - short story sequel "No Place Like Earth" |- style="vertical-align:top;" <!--format-->|Comic <!--year -->|1985-1989 <!--cause -->|War <!--title -->|''[[Appleseed (manga)|Appleseed]]'' <!--desc -->|[[Masamune Shirow]] - Japanese [[manga]] (and subsequent [[anime]] adaptations) |- style="vertical-align:top;" <!--format-->|Novella <!--Year -->|1989 <!--cause -->|Zombies <!--title -->|''[[On the Far Side of the Cadillac Desert With Dead Folks]]'' <!--desc -->|[[Joe R. Lansdale]] |- style="vertical-align:top;" <!--format-->|Comic <!--year -->|1990-1995 <!--cause -->|War <!--title -->|''[[Battle Angel Alita]]'' <!--desc -->|[[Yukito Kishiro]] - manga series containing post-apocalyptic elements and taking place in a highly futuristic dystopian world |- style="vertical-align:top;" <!--format-->|Comic <!--year -->|2000-2014 <!--cause -->|Impact event, war <!--title -->|''[[Battle Angel Alita: Last Order]]'' <!--desc -->|[[Yukito Kishiro]] - a continuation of the former manga series containing the same elements as previous but goes into greater detail as to how the dystopia came about |- style="vertical-align:top;" <!--format-->|Novel <!--year -->|1913 <!--cause -->|Disease <!--title -->|''Goslings: A World of Women''<ref>[http://jameswharris.wordpress.com/2014/05/11/forgotten-science-fiction-goslings-by-j-d-beresford/ Forgotten Science Fiction: Goslings by J. D. Beresford]. Auxiliary Memory 5-11-2014. Retrieved on 5-14-2014.</ref> <!--desc -->|[[J. D. Beresford|J.D. Beresford]] - A global plague has decimated England's male population and the once-predictable Gosling family is now free to fulfill its long-frustrated desires. |- style="vertical-align:top;" <!--format-->|Novel <!--year -->|1805 <!--cause -->|Human decline <!--title -->|''[[Le Dernier Homme]]'' <!--desc -->|[[Jean-Baptiste Cousin de Grainville]] - regarded as the first story of modern speculative fiction to depict the end of the world<ref name=wesleyan>{{cite web |url=http://www.upne.com/0-8195-6549-0.html |title=The Last Man |author= |date= |publisher=University Press of New England |accessdate=September 30, 2011}}</ref> |- style="vertical-align:top;" <!--format-->|Comic <!--year -->|1997- <!--cause -->|War <!--title -->|''[[Desert Punk]]'' <!--desc -->|[[Usune Masatoshi|Usune Masatosh]]<nowiki/>i - ongoing manga series (later adapted into an anime) |- style="vertical-align:top;" <!--format-->|Comic <!--year -->|1986-1993 <!--cause -->|War <!--title -->|''[[Ex-Mutants]]'' <!--desc -->|Set in a post-nuclear world |- style="vertical-align:top;" <!--format-->|Comic <!--year -->|1968- <!--cause -->|War <!--title -->|''[[Cobalt 60 (comics)|Cobalt 60]]'' <!--desc -->|Created by Vaughn Bodé, first published in 1968 |- style="vertical-align:top;" <!--format-->|Comic <!--year -->|2002 <!--cause -->|War <!--title -->|''[[Incredible Hulk: The End: The Last Titan]]'' <!--desc -->| |- style="vertical-align:top;" <!--format-->|Comic <!--year -->|2003 <!--cause -->|War <!--title -->|''[[Judge Dredd vs. Aliens]]'' <!--desc -->| |- style="vertical-align:top;" <!--format-->|Comic <!--year -->|1972- <!--cause -->|War <!--title -->|''[[Kamandi]]'' <!--desc -->|Featuring the ''Last Boy on Earth'' series, first published in 1972 |- style="vertical-align:top;" <!--format-->|Comic <!--year -->|2000-2001 <!--cause -->|War <!--title -->|''[[Saikano]]'' <!--desc -->|[[Shin Takahashi]] - manga series |- style="vertical-align:top;" <!--format-->|Comic <!--year -->|1990-1991 <!--cause -->|War <!--title -->|''[[The Last American]]'' <!--desc -->|Series originally from [[Marvel Comics|Marvel]] in 1990/1991, re-released by [[Com.X]] |- style="vertical-align:top;" <!--format-->|Comic <!--year -->|2004 <!--cause -->|War <!--title -->|''[[The Punisher: The End]]'' <!--desc -->| |- style="vertical-align:top;" <!--format-->|Comic <!--year -->|1992- <!--cause -->|War <!--title -->|''[[X/1999]]'' <!--desc -->|[[Clamp (manga artists)|Clamp]] - ongoing manga series |- style="vertical-align:top;" <!--format-->|Song <!--year -->|1992 <!--cause -->|War <!--title -->|"April 2031" <!--desc -->|Song by the band [[Warrant (American band)|Warrant]] on the ''Dog Eat Dog'' album; depicts an Earth devastated by war where life lives on only by artificial means |- style="vertical-align:top;" <!--format-->|Other <!--year -->|1995- <!--cause -->|War <!--title -->|[[Ayreon]] <!--desc -->|[[Arjen Anthony Lucassen]] - series of concept albums depicting the end of life on Earth in 2084 due to, among other factors, a catastrophic nuclear war |- style="vertical-align:top;" <!--format-->|Poem <!--year -->|1956 <!--cause -->|War <!--title -->|"The Horses" <!--desc -->|[[Edwin Muir]] - deals with society's regression to pre-[[Industrial Revolution]] conditions in the wake of a nuclear war |- style="vertical-align:top;" <!--format-->|Poem <!--year -->|1961 <!--cause -->|War <!--title -->|"Your Attention Please" <!--desc -->|[[Peter Porter (poet)|Peter Porter]] - written in the style of a radio broadcast warning of an impending nuclear attack |- style="vertical-align:top;" <!--format-->|Song <!--year -->|1979 <!--cause -->|War <!--title -->|"Your Attention Please" <!--desc -->|Song adaptation of the above Porter poem, written and recorded by the [[Scotland|Scottish]] [[post-punk]] group the [[Scars (band)|Scars]] |- style="vertical-align:top;" <!--format-->|Game <!--year -->|2008 <!--cause -->|Impact event <!--title -->|''[[Advance Wars: Days of Ruin]]'' <!--desc -->|With virtually all of humanity wiped out by a meteor strike, the game follows the exploits of an army of survivors, fighting bandit raiders and hostile armies across the planet's desolate remains. |- style="vertical-align:top;" <!--format-->|Other <!--year -->|2004- <!--cause -->|Impact event <!--title -->|''[[Compilation of Final Fantasy VII]]'' <!--desc -->|Includes video games, short stories, and animated features; revolves largely around the fate of a planet which is ravaged by the impact a giant meteor/asteroid, summoned by magic; published between 2004 and 2009 |- style="vertical-align:top;" <!--format-->|Game <!--year -->|2007 <!--cause -->|Impact event <!--title -->|''[[Godzilla: Unleashed]]'' <!--desc -->|PC video game, from Pipeworks, set in the post-apocalyptic earth in which Earth has been destroyed by crystals |- style="vertical-align:top;" <!--format-->|Game <!--year -->|2011 <!--cause -->|Impact event <!--title -->|''[[Rage (video game)|Rage]]'' <!--desc -->|Video game by iD Software; set after a meteor collision with the Earth |- style="vertical-align:top;" <!--format-->|Novel <!--year -->|1997- <!--cause -->|Aliens <!--title -->|''[[Outlanders]]'' <!--desc -->|Novel series created by [[Mark Ellis (American author)|Mark Ellis]], aka James Axler |- style="vertical-align:top;" <!--format-->|Novel <!--year -->|1967-1988 <!--cause -->|Aliens <!--title -->|''[[The Tripods]]'' <!--desc -->|[[Samuel Youd|John Christopher]] -
